title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of the strategies outlined in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To maintain the status quo

options.label: B
options.text: To expand the frame of the possible

options.label: C
options.text: To choose a defining fight

options.label: D
options.text: To secure an early win

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Arab Spring in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an example of a successful social movement

options.label: B
options.text: It is an example of a failed social movement

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the importance of securing an early win

options.label: D
options.text: It shows the power of expanding the frame of the possible

multiple-choice.question: What is the key characteristic of a defining fight?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a fight that is easily won

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fight that is easily lost

options.label: C
options.text: It is a fight that captures the essence of the change desired

options.label: D
options.text: It is a fight that is not worth fighting

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of securing an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates momentum and changes what people think is possible

options.label: B
options.text: It is not important in achieving lasting change

options.label: C
options.text: It is only important for short-term gains

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important for individual success

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the U.S. Civil Rights Movement in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an example of a successful social movement

options.label: B
options.text: It is an example of a failed social movement

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the importance of securing an early win

options.label: D
options.text: It shows the power of expanding the frame of the possible

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the media in securing an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore the issue

options.label: B
options.text: To report on the issue in a neutral way

options.label: C
options.text: To change the narrative and make arguments in public

options.label: D
options.text: To not report on the issue at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of living like a citizen?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not important in achieving lasting change

options.label: B
options.text: It is only important for individual success

options.label: C
options.text: It is essential in turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important for short-term gains

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Cold War Poland solidarity movement in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an example of a failed social movement

options.label: B
options.text: It is an example of a successful social movement

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the importance of securing an early win

options.label: D
options.text: It shows the power of expanding the frame of the possible

multiple-choice.question: What is the key characteristic of a long, slow slog?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a quick and easy process

options.label: B
options.text: It is a difficult and sustained process

options.label: C
options.text: It is a process that is not worth pursuing

options.label: D
options.text: It is a process that is only important for individual success

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary message of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That protests are not effective in achieving lasting change

options.label: B
options.text: That anyone can be part of the process of turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power

options.label: C
options.text: That securing an early win is the most important strategy

options.label: D
options.text: That expanding the frame of the possible is the most important strategy

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self-assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where unordered parts come together in an organized structure.

options.label: B
options.text: A process where ordered parts come together in a disorganized structure.

options.label: C
options.text: A process where living organisms grow and adapt independently.

options.label: D
options.text: A process where non-living objects are created through traditional means.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self-assembly in biology?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of proteins, DNA, and RNA.

options.label: B
options.text: The replication of cells.

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of viruses.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self-assembly in non-living objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Magnets.

options.label: B
options.text: Snowflakes.

options.label: C
options.text: Robotics.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using self-assembly in engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To make technologies easier to build.

options.label: B
options.text: To make technologies more adaptive.

options.label: C
options.text: To make technologies less reliant on fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self-assembly in engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating molecular microchips for computers.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating 3D structures with DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: Creating robots.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of using self-assembly in engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To make technologies easier to build.

options.label: B
options.text: To make technologies more adaptive.

options.label: C
options.text: To make technologies less reliant on fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible application of self-assembly in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating factories that are more like organisms or brains.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating construction sites that are like gardens that grow and adapt independently.

options.label: C
options.text: Creating robots that can repair themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self-assembly in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of cities.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of galaxies.

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of snowflakes.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of proteins that allows them to self-assemble?

options.label: A
options.text: The interaction between amino acids and the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: The interaction between amino acids and other proteins.

options.label: C
options.text: The shape of the protein.

options.label: D
options.text: The size of the protein.

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of using self-assembly to create 3D structures with DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: To make technologies easier to build.

options.label: B
options.text: To make technologies more adaptive.

options.label: C
options.text: To deliver drugs inside the body.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of cognitive diversity, and how does it impact collective intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive diversity refers to the presence of different perspectives, experiences, and ways of thinking within a group, leading to a significant increase in collective intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive diversity refers to the presence of similar perspectives, experiences, and ways of thinking within a group, leading to a decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Cognitive diversity is not a relevant concept in the modern economy.

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive diversity is only relevant in simple tasks, not complex ones.

multiple-choice.question: Why are people attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it validates their world view and makes them feel smarter.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a natural human behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a necessary aspect of innovation.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a complex task.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of surrounding oneself with like-minded individuals in complex tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: A significant increase in collective intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: A lack of uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: No impact on collective intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: Why is cognitive diversity important for organizations in the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it will become a key feature of competitive advantage.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a necessary aspect of innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a complex task.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not relevant in the modern economy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of collective intelligence, and how is it impacted by cognitive diversity?

options.label: A
options.text: Collective intelligence refers to the presence of different perspectives, experiences, and ways of thinking within a group, leading to a significant increase in collective intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Collective intelligence refers to the presence of similar perspectives, experiences, and ways of thinking within a group, leading to a decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Collective intelligence is not a relevant concept in the modern economy.

options.label: D
options.text: Collective intelligence is only relevant in simple tasks, not complex ones.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it wrong to believe that one's own model is the best, and that one should work with others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a natural human behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a necessary aspect of innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a complex task.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is spectacularly wrong.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of mirroring each other's perspectives in complex tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: A significant increase in collective intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: A lack of uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: No impact on collective intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: Why is cognitive diversity essential for achieving collective intelligence and solving complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it requires a shift in perspective, away from the comfort of working with like-minded individuals and towards embracing diverse perspectives and experiences.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a necessary aspect of innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a complex task.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not relevant in the modern economy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of cognitive diversity in the modern economy?

options.label: A
options.text: It will become a key feature of competitive advantage in the next 50 years.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a necessary for innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a complex task.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant in the modern economy.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to prioritize cognitive diversity in organizations?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it will become a key feature of competitive advantage in the next 50 years.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is necessary for innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a complex task.

options.label: D
